indications: Abscesses, suppurative inflammation, ulcerations, and snakebite (topical)
Intestinal parasites especially when there are signs of accumulation

action.primary: Dries Dampness, expels Phlegm, stops malarial disorders and settles Wind

contraindications: Contraindicated for those with Yin or Blood Deficiency.
Contraindicated for those with malnutrition due to Ying Wei Disharmony.
Do not use long term or topically in a large area.
Do not use in decoction or mixed with hot water.

useCases: Topically for scabies with cracked, itching skin that worsens at night with weeping lesions from scratching.
Ulcerations of the mouth, tongue and throat.
Wind-Damp sores or tineal itching or itching from dermatosis. (topical)
Sores with redness, swelling, itching and pain. (topical)
Internally and topically for poisonous snake bites.
Abscesses and other hard suppurative lesions.
Internally for severe abdominal pain due to parasitic accumulations in the intestines.
Excessive Phlegm obstruction accompanying childhood convul-sions.
As a tincture for herpes zoster.

notes: Realgar was one of the main minerals used in Taoist alchemy. It was believed to possess the ability to transform copper into gold.
It can be used alone with warm water for asthma.
It is effective in resisting the growth of cancer cells.
For a lower abdominal mass and dysuria, insert honey-coated pills of Xiong Huang into the vagina.
Nasal polyps can be treated by blowing the powder into the nostrils.

Both Xiong Huang and Sulfur #{LiuHuang} Liu Huang resolve toxicity and kill parasites and are used in treating scabies, tinea and rashes. Liu Huang is better against tinea and itching lesions, its hot nature makes it unsuitable for treating Yang lesions. Xiong Huang is more effective at resolving toxins and treating abscesses and sores.
